req-resp

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /*! \file req-resp
00002     \brief This file is not part of the driver sources.  The contents of this
00003            file are used in HTML document generation.
00004 */
00005 
00006 /*! \page  reqresp Request processing using the OCTEON PCI driver
00007 
00008 This section describes the steps involved in sending a request to OCTEON.
00009 
00010 <br>
00011 <br>
00012 \section rr-sec1 OCTEON Input queue initialization.
00013 
00014 The OCTEON PCI host driver (provided as a linux kernel module in the
00015 OCTEON-PCI-BASE package) is responsible for the initialization of all OCTEON
00016 devices in the system.
00017 
00018 During initialization, the driver would allocate memory for the instruction
00019 queue used for OCTEON PCI input. For each instruction queue (also referred to
00020 as input queues), the driver allocates a contiguous memory in host memory that
00021 can accomodate a fixed number of instructions. The starting address of each
00022 queue and the number of instructions it accomodates are programmed into OCTEON
00023 by the driver. OCTEON supports instructions that are 32 or 64 bytes in size.
00024 
00025 <br>
00026 <br>
00027 \section rr-sec2 OCTEON PCI driver application interfaces
00028 
00029  The driver provides ioctl's that can be used by user-space applications to
00030  send requests to OCTEON. A user-space library provides a set of API's that act
00031 as wrappers around these ioctls. User-space applications are encouraged to use
00032 the API's rather than ioctl. This will allow the applications to be independent
00033 of any low-level changes in the ioctl interface of the driver. The driver also
00034 exports API's usable by kernel-space applications. Both set of API's are
00035 explained in more detail later on in this chapter.
00036 
00037 <br>
00038 <br>
00039  \section rr-sec3 Driver interaction with OCTEON for request processing
00040 
00041  To send a request to OCTEON, applications in user-space call the user-space
00042  library API (which in turn calls the OCTEON driver ioctl). Kernel applications
00043 use a different set of API exported by the driver. In all cases, the request has
00044 to be sent to the driver in a format defined by the OCTEON_soft_request_t
00045 structure.
00046 
00047  All requests get converted to a instruction format that is understood by the
00048  OCTEON PCI input queues. Each such instruction is copied into the next
00049  available location in the instruction queue. The driver notifies availability
00050  of new instructions to OCTEON by writing to a doorbell register.
00051 
00052  The OCTEON PCI input queue hardware gets the data pointer from the instruction
00053  and fetches all data and buffers it internally in a work queue entry. OCTEON 
00054 IPD would schedule the work to one of the cores when the core software requests
00055 work from the hardware. The core gets the data (and instruction contents if it
00056 was a RAW packet) for the instruction, processes it locally and send a response
00057 back to host. If a response is required, the instruction would also have a
00058 return pointer which gives the physical address in host memory where the
00059 response should be returned.
00060 
00061 
00062  \anchor PCIcmd32
00063  \section rr-cmd32 PCI Input Queue command format
00064 
00065  The driver uses a 32-byte command for the Input Queues by default. The first
00066  16 bytes of the command are defined by the hardware. The PCI instruction
00067  format is explained in section 10.3.1. in the CN38XX/CN58XX hardware manual
00068  and in section 9.4.1 in CN56XX Hardware manual.The contents of the
00069  remaining 16 bytes is setup under the driver's control. The 32-byte command
00070  format is as shown below:
00071 
00072 
00073 \verbatim
00074   -----------------------------
00075  |    Data Pointer       (64-bit) |   Hardware defined
00076   --------------------------------
00077  | Instruction Header    (64-bit) |   Hardware defined
00078   --------------------------------
00079  | Return Data Pointer   (64-bit) |   Driver defined
00080   --------------------------------
00081  | Input Response Header (64-bit) |   Driver defined
00082   --------------------------------
00083 \endverbatim
00084 
00085  <b>  Figure 1: 32-byte PCI Input Queue Command format  </b>
00086 
00087  The data pointer points to a buffer or a gather list of buffers
00088  in host memory where the input data is located. The instruction header (IH)
00089  format can be found in the hardware manual.
00090 
00091  The return data pointer (rptr) points to a buffer or a scatter list of buffers
00092  in host memory where the application running on OCTEON is expected to send
00093  the response data.
00094 
00095 
00096  The Input Response Header (IRH) is specified by the driver and has the
00097  following format:
00098 
00099 
00100  \verbatim
00101    63      48 47      40 39       34 33     20  19   18       16 15           0
00102    ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00103   | Opcode   |  Param   | Dest Port | rlenssz |  S  | pcie_port | Request ID   |
00104    ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00105 \endverbatim 
00106 
00107  <b> Figure 2:  Input Response Header format </b>
00108 
00109  Field Description:
00110  - opcode & param : application defined values to identify the payload type.
00111  - Destport : application defined value to identify the destination; usually an
00112 OCTEON I/O port.
00113  - rlenssz : data length if rptr is a single buffer; count of buffers in
00114  gather list if rptr points to a scatter list.
00115  - S : indicates if rptr points to a scatter list.
00116  - pcie_port - indicates which PCIe interface should be used to send the
00117 response back to host.
00118  - Request ID : index in the driver data structure to identify the request.
00119 
00120 
00121 
00122 <br>
00123 <br>
00124 <br>
00125 
00126 \section rr-sec4 OCTEON Request format
00127 
00128  As mentioned before, to send a request to OCTEON, the application should fill a
00129  OCTEON_soft_request_t structure and call the kernel/user-space api to send the
00130  request. The structure definition can be found in
00131 components/driver/host/include/cavium_defs.h.
00132 
00133 The following fields must be filled by the caller:
00134 
00135  1. inbuf  - set the number of input buffers, address and size of each buffer.
00136              It is legal to have 0 input buffers.
00137 
00138  2. outbuf - set the number of output buffers, address and size of each buffer.
00139              It is legal to have 0 output buffers if no response is expected.
00140              Output buffers must be allocated if a response is expected.
00141              Kernel applications must allocate an additional 16 bytes to
00142              accomodate the response header and status of a response.
00143              For user-space applications, driver will allocate the extra bytes.
00144 
00145  3. ih     - instruction header bits. Refer to the OCTEON Hardware Manual 
00146              (section 10.3.1) for the format and usage.
00147 
00148  4. irh    -  The opcode field should be set. Optionally the param and dport
00149               fields can also be set. All other fields are set by the driver
00150               and should not be set by the application.
00151               See driver/common/OCTEON-opcodes.h for opcodes reserved for use by
00152               driver and applications released by Cavium.
00153 
00154  5. exhdr  - upto 4 additional 64-bit values can be passed which will be
00155              added to the front of the request data bytes.
00156 
00157  6. exhdr_info - Just the exhdr_count field needs to be set.
00158 
00159  7. req_info - The following field needs to be set by application.
00160     \li OCTEON_id - OCTEON device id.
00161     \li req_mask  - Set the response order, response mode, dma mode and
00162                     instruction queue to use.
00163     \li timeout   - time in millisecs to wait for response.
00164     \li callback  - should not be set by user space application. Kernel
00165                     applications can set it to a function pointer.
00166     \li callback_arg - additional argument to be passed to callback by driver.
00167                     Should not be set by user application.
00168     \li status    - Should not be set by any application. Driver will return
00169                     status in this field.
00170     \li request_id - Should  not be set by any application. Driver will return
00171                      request id after request is posted to OCTEON.
00172 
00173  If the call returns success, the current state of the request will be in the
00174  req_info.status field of the request.
00175 
00176 \anchor  octsoftreqformat
00177  Note: There are some changes to OCTEON_soft_request_t in the 1.0 release. To
00178        continue using the old format, recompile the driver after enabling the
00179        CVM_SUPPORT_DEPRECATED_API flag in
00180        components/driver/host/include/cavium_defs.h. The changes in 1.0 were
00181        made to enable support for 32-bit user-space apps to communicate with    
00182        the driver in a 64-bit kernel. The changes are listed below:
00183 
00184        - The OCTEON_request_info_t structure does not have the callback and
00185           callback_arg fields when used in user-space applications.
00186        - The datatype for req_info field in OCTEON_soft_request_t and
00187           for ptr field in OCTEON_buffer_t have changed from a pointer type
00188           to a union which includes a pointer and a uint64_t value.
00189 
00190        The following macros allow application to transparently access the
00191        modified fields:
00192        - SOFT_REQ_INBUF(sr, idx)
00193        - SOFT_REQ_OUTBUF(sr, idx)
00194        - SOFT_REQ_INFO(sr)
00195 
00196       where sr is a pointer to a OCTEON_soft_request_t structure.
00197 
00198 
00199  The response sent by the core application to any request is expected in the 
00200  following format:
00201 
00202 \verbatim
00203  -----------------------------
00204  | Response Header (8 bytes) |
00205  -----------------------------
00206  | Response Data             |
00207  -----------------------------
00208  | Status word     (8 bytes) |
00209  -----------------------------
00210 \endverbatim
00211  <b>  Figure 3: Response buffer format  </b>
00212 
00213 
00214 
00215  Kernel applications should take care that the response (output) buffer 
00216  is created in the above format. For user-space application, the driver
00217  builds the buffer in the required format.
00218 
00219  \verbatim
00220    63    48 47         42 41              20     19     18              0
00221   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
00222   | Opcode | Source Port | Destination Port | Reserved |   Request ID   |
00223   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
00224 \endverbatim 
00225  <b> Figure 4:  Response Header format </b>
00226 
00227 
00228 
00229  \verbatim
00230    63        32 31                    16 15              8 7            0
00231   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
00232   | Reserved   | Application Identifier | Request Status  | DMA status  |
00233   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
00234 \endverbatim 
00235  <b> Figure 5:  Status word format </b>
00236 
00237   Only the lower 4 bytes of the status word currently hold the completion
00238   status. The upper 4 bytes are reserved. Of the lower 2 bytes, the most
00239   significant 2 bytes is used as an application identifier. The least
00240   significant 2 bytes hold a 16-bit status value.
00241 
00242   <b> NOTE:</b> The last 8 bits of status word is used as a DMA completion
00243         indicator by the driver. Applications have the 24-bits as
00244         shown above for their use. If more than 255 error conditions can 
00245         occur in an application, it can reserve multiple application 
00246         identifiers. The application identifier value 0 is reserved for the
00247         driver.
00248 
00249  The OCTEON host driver looks at the 8 byte status word for completion of a 
00250  request. When a request is sent, the driver initializes it to all f's.
00251  The driver keeps checking that byte[0] of status word changes from 0xff
00252  to any other value to consider the request completed.
00253 
00254  <b>NOTE:</b> It is illegal for core applications to set byte[0]
00255  of the status word to 0xff.
00256 
00257 
00258  The next sections describe the response mode, dma mode and response order that
00259  can be used with requests sent to the driver.
00260 
00261 
00262 <br>
00263 <br>
00264  \subsection rr-subsec4-1 RESPONSE ORDER 
00265 
00266  The driver supports the following response ordering mechanisms:
00267 
00268  1. <b>ORDERED:</b>
00269              An ordered request's response is delivered to the caller only
00270              after all previous ORDERED requests have received their responses.
00271              This is true even if the timeout values for a ordered
00272              request is less than the previous ordered requests. This is the
00273              recommended mode to use for kernel-level applications.
00274 
00275  2. <b>UNORDERED:</b>
00276              Unordered requests can complete in any order. UNORDERED mode
00277              requests are the preferred mode for user-space applications.
00278              A user-space application can specify blocking (the function call
00279              will not return till a response is received or its times-out) 
00280              or non-blocking (the function call returns immediately). For 
00281              non-blocking mode, the user-space application is expected to query 
00282              for the status of the request at frequent intervals till the status
00283              for the request returned indicates that the request completed or
00284              timed-out.
00285 
00286 3. <b>NORESPONSE:</b> These requests don't expect a response. The driver buffers
00287              them internally only as long as it takes OCTEON to read them in.
00288              These type of requests can be sent from kernel and user space
00289              applications.
00290 
00291 <br>
00292 <br>
00293  \subsection rr-subsec4-2 RESPONSE MODE
00294 
00295  The driver supports the following response modes for UNORDERED requests:
00296 
00297  1. <b>BLOCKING:</b> The driver will not return from the ioctl till the requests
00298               completes (or times-out).
00299 
00300  2. <b>NON-BLOCKING:</b>
00301               The driver returns as soon as the request is submitted to OCTEON.
00302               The user application is required to poll for completion of the
00303               request using a query api function.
00304 
00305 
00306  For kernel-space applications, all requests are considered NON-BLOCKING
00307  operations by the driver.
00308 
00309 
00310 <br>
00311 <br>
00312 \subsection rr-subsec4-3 DMA MODES 
00313 
00314  The driver supports the following DMA modes:
00315 
00316  1. <b>DIRECT:</b>
00317              In this mode, there is a single input buffer pointer (dptr) in the
00318              instruction and a single output buffer pointer (rptr).
00319 
00320  2. <b>GATHER:</b>
00321              In this mode, there can be multiple input buffer pointers. Driver
00322              creates a gather list with these pointers and passes address of
00323              gather list in the instruction. There is only one output buffer.
00324 
00325  3. <b>SCATTER:</b>
00326              There is only one input buffer. There can be multiple output buffer
00327              pointers. Driver creates a scatter list with these pointers and
00328              passes address of scatter list in the instruction.
00329 
00330  4. <b>SCATTER_GATHER:</b>
00331              There can be multiple input and output buffers. Driver creates
00332              a gather and scatter list and passes the address of these lists in
00333              the instrcution.
00334 
00335 
00336 <br>
00337 <br>
00338 <br>
00339  \section user_space_support Supported Modes for user-space applications.
00340 
00341  For user-space applications, the supported modes are described below. All 
00342  constants used below are defined in components/driver/host/include/cavium_defs.h.
00343 
00344  1. <b>DIRECT DMA:</b>
00345               Multiple Input or Output buffers are allowed.
00346               Multiple input buffers are coalesced internally by the driver.
00347               Multiple output buffers are also supported. Driver gets
00348               response in a single response buffer and splits it among the
00349               multiple user-space output buffers.
00350               Maximum Input data size is OCT_MAX_DIRECT_INPUT_DATA_SIZE.
00351               Maximum Output data size is OCT_MAX_DIRECT_OUTPUT_DATA_SIZE.
00352 
00353 
00354  2. <b>GATHER DMA:</b>
00355               Multiple Input or Output buffers are allowed.
00356               Multiple input buffers are put into a gather list. Maximum 
00357               gather input data cannot exceed OCT_MAX_GATHER_DATA_SIZE.
00358               Multiple output buffers are also supported. Driver gets
00359               response in a single response buffer and splits it among the
00360               multiple user-space output buffers. Maximum output data size
00361               cannot exceed OCT_MAX_DIRECT_OUTPUT_DATA_SIZE.
00362 
00363 
00364  3. <b>SCATTER DMA:</b>
00365               Multiple Input or Output buffers are allowed.
00366               Multiple input buffers are coalesced internally by the driver.
00367               Maximum input data cannot exceed OCT_MAX_DIRECT_INPUT_DATA_SIZE.
00368               Multiple output buffers are put into a scatter list. Driver 
00369               splits the response from internal scatter buffers among the
00370               multiple user-space output buffers. Maximum output data size
00371               cannot exceed OCT_MAX_SCATTER_DATA_SIZE.
00372 
00373 
00374  4. <b>SCATTER_GATHER DMA:</b>
00375               Multiple Input or Output buffers are allowed.
00376               Multiple input buffers are put into a gather list. Maximum 
00377               gather input data cannot exceed OCT_MAX_GATHER_DATA_SIZE.
00378               Multiple output buffers are put into a scatter list. Driver 
00379               splits the response from internal scatter buffers among the
00380               multiple user-space output buffers. Maximum output data size
00381               cannot exceed OCT_MAX_SCATTER_DATA_SIZE.
00382 
00383 
00384 
00385  The following response mode and response orders are supported:
00386 
00387 \verbatim
00388     Response Order  |  Response mode
00389  ---------------------------------------
00390  1. UNORDERED       |  BLOCKING
00391 
00392  2. UNORDERED       |  NON-BLOCKING
00393 
00394  3. NORESPONSE      |  NON-BLOCKING
00395 \endverbatim
00396  
00397 <b>IMPORTANT</b> ORDERED response order is not supported for user-space applications.
00398 
00399 
00400 <br>
00401 <br>
00402 <br>
00403 \section kernel_space_support Supported Modes for kernel-space applications.
00404  
00405  For kernel-space applications, the supported modes are described below. All  constants used below are defined in components/driver/host/include/cavium_defs.h.
00406 
00407 
00408  1. <b>DIRECT DMA:</b>
00409               Multiple Input buffers are allowed.
00410               Multiple input buffers are coalesced internally by the driver.
00411               Multiple output buffers are not supported.
00412               Maximum Input data size is OCT_MAX_DIRECT_INPUT_DATA_SIZE.
00413               Maximum Output data size is OCT_MAX_DIRECT_OUTPUT_DATA_SIZE.
00414 
00415  2. <b>GATHER DMA:</b>
00416               Multiple Input buffers are allowed.
00417               Multiple input buffers are put into a gather list. Maximum 
00418               gather input data cannot exceed OCT_MAX_GATHER_DATA_SIZE.
00419               Multiple output buffers are not supported. Maximum output data
00420               size cannot exceed OCT_MAX_DIRECT_OUTPUT_DATA_SIZE.
00421 
00422  3. <b>SCATTER DMA:</b>
00423               Multiple Input buffers are not allowed.
00424               Maximum input data cannot exceed OCT_MAX_DIRECT_INPUT_DATA_SIZE.
00425               Multiple output buffers are put into a scatter list. Maximum
00426               output data size cannot exceed OCT_MAX_SCATTER_DATA_SIZE. 
00427 
00428  4. <b>SCATTER_GATHER DMA:</b>
00429               Multiple Input or Output buffers are allowed.
00430               Multiple input buffers are put into a gather list. Maximum 
00431               gather input data cannot exceed OCT_MAX_GATHER_DATA_SIZE.
00432               Multiple output buffers are put into a scatter list. The core
00433               driver has the responsibility to DMA the response data into the
00434               buffers pointed by the scatter list.
00435               Maximum output data size cannot exceed OCT_MAX_SCATTER_DATA_SIZE.
00436 
00437 <b>NOTE: </b> Kernel applications are required to reserve 8 bytes at the start
00438               of the output buffer for Response Header and 8 bytes at the end of
00439               the output buffer for status bytes. Thus, the actual output buffer
00440               size constraints is the maximum data size mentioned in
00441               the above paragraphs + 16 bytes. For e.g., to receive the maximum
00442               DIRECT DMA data size of OCT_MAX_DIRECT_OUTPUT_DATA_SIZE (16367
00443               bytes) the application should allocate a buffer of size 16383
00444               bytes.
00445 
00446 
00447 
00448  <b>IMPORTANT</b>:
00449  The driver supports ORDERED and NORESPONSE type requests for kernel
00450  applications. UNORDERED response order is supported, but is not recommended.
00451 
00452  For kernel-space applications, all requests are considered NON-BLOCKING
00453  operations by the driver.
00454 
00455 
00456 <br>
00457 <br>
00458 <br>
00459  \section driver_kernel_api  Request processing from kernel applications
00460 
00461     The OCTEON host driver provides two functions as entry points for kernel 
00462     applications into the driver to support request/response with the OCTEON
00463     device. The driver allows kernel level requests to specify a callback which 
00464     will be called by the driver on request completion. A request can send
00465     data in a single buffer, in multiple buffers (in which case the driver
00466     coalesces the buffers into one big buffer) or a gather list of data 
00467     buffers. The application can use multiple buffers to get the response if
00468     SCATTER dma mode is used, in which case the driver would create a scatter
00469     list which would be used by the core driver to copy the response to host.
00470 
00471 <br>
00472    \subsection kernel_api  API for kernel space applications
00473 
00474     1. OCTEON_process_request() - Kernel space applications use this API to 
00475        send a request to OCTEON. All 3 response modes described above are
00476        supported. ORDERED and NORESPONSE mode requests are recommended for
00477        kernel space applications. The required information for a request is
00478        filled in a  OCTEON_soft_request_t structure and passed along with the
00479        OCTEON device id as parameters to this function.
00480        When this function returns success, the request has been queued
00481        successfully by the driver though it may not have been sent yet to OCTEON.
00482        A callback may be specified with the request. The callback function will
00483        be called by the driver when,
00484        \li for ORDERED/UNORDERED: response is received or the request timed-out.
00485        \li for NORESPONSE mode: request is sent to OCTEON or if it times-out.
00486 
00487        In case of a time out, the driver returns a status value of  
00488        OCTEON_REQUEST_TIMEOUT (decimal 3). A response from the core could also
00489        give an error value, but it should never be 3 as that value is reserved
00490        for the driver.
00491 
00492 
00493    2. OCTEON_query_request_status() - Kernel space applications call this 
00494       function to determine the status of a previously posted UNORDERED request.
00495       The request id is presented to the driver in a OCTEON_query_request_t
00496       structure. The current status of the request is returned by the driver in
00497       the same structure. The status returned can be one of
00498       \li OCTEON_REQUEST_PENDING - the request has not yet completed
00499       \li OCTEON_REQUEST_TIMEOUT - the request timed-out before completion
00500       \li 32-bit value - which is returned by the application on the core
00501       that processed the request. Its value is application dependent.
00502 
00503 
00504 <br>
00505    \subsection  kern_samp  Kernel-space application example sources
00506 
00507     The kernel-space application example under
00508  components/driver/host/test/kernel/req_resp demonstrates request processing
00509 using the OCTEON PCI driver. It requires the <b>cvmcs</b> core application which
00510 can be found at applications/pci-core-app/base.
00511 
00512 <br>
00513 <br>
00514 <br>
00515  \section driver_user_api  Request processing from user space  applications
00516 
00517         ORDERED mode requests are not supported for user space requests. For
00518     NORESPONSE type of requests, blocking mode is not supported. User mode
00519     requests cannot specify a callback. Requests can be blocking or
00520     non-blocking.
00521     User space applications can send requests with the input in multiple
00522     buffers. The driver would copy all the input data into one buffer.
00523     The driver does not support zero-copy gather/scatter with multiple
00524     user-space buffers but supports a 1-copy operation for all user-space
00525     input data buffers. User-space applications can give multiple user-space
00526     buffers to receive the output data. If multiple buffers are specified,
00527     the driver scatters the output data into the user-space output buffers
00528     appropriately. 
00529 
00530 <br>
00531   \subsection dev_file_sec OCTEON device file.
00532 
00533     Before any user applications can start using the OCTEON driver, a
00534     device file should be created. The OCTEON device file is a character 
00535     device with major number 127 named /dev/OCTEON_device.
00536     The OCTEON user api library (liboctapi.a) looks for this device file.
00537     Note that there is only one device file even when there are multiple
00538     OCTEON devices in the system. The device file should be considered as
00539     a entry point to the driver. Each of the ioctls supported by the driver
00540     has a field identifying the OCTEON device at which the operation is
00541     directed.
00542 
00543 
00544 <br>
00545    \subsection ioctl_sec OCTEON driver ioctls and user level API.
00546 
00547  Once the file has been opened, there are several ioctl's that enable access
00548  to the OCTEON device. They provide read/write access to the OCTEON registers
00549  and to send requests. The octapi library provides wrappers for all ioctls.
00550  The ioctls are defined in OCTEON_SDK/components/driver/host/include/OCTEON_ioctl.h.
00551  The preferred method though is to use the octapi library. Check out
00552  OCTEON_SDK/components/driver/api/OCTEON_user.h for all the api functions
00553  available.
00554 
00555 
00556 
00557  A request from user space can send the data in multiple input buffers and the
00558  result can arrive in multiple output buffers as desired by the user.
00559 
00560     \subsection  user_api API for user space applications.
00561 
00562     1. OCTEON_initialize() - This function opens the OCTEON device file and
00563         enables a channel of communication with the OCTEON device driver.
00564 
00565     2. OCTEON_send_request() - User space applications can send a request by
00566         filling up a OCTEON_soft_request_t structure and calling this function
00567         with the OCTEON device id. User-space applications can send 
00568         UNORDERED (blocking or non-blocking) and NORESPONSE mode requests.
00569         For non-blocking UNORDERED requests, the caller is expected to query
00570         the request's status. For UNORDERED BLOCKING mode, the status is
00571         available in the soft request structure when the call returns. For all
00572         modes, if the request was queued successfully, the function returns
00573         success, else it returns a errno value describing the error encountered.
00574 
00575     3. OCTEON_query_request() - User space applications use this function to
00576         query the status of a previously posted UNORDERED non-blocking request.
00577         The mechanism used and the return values are the same as for a kernel
00578         space OCTEON_query_request_status() call. See above.
00579 
00580     4. OCTEON_shutdown() - This function closes the OCTEON device file and stops
00581         the channel of communication to the OCTEON driver.
00582 
00583 
00584 <br>
00585    \subsection  cmd64  Using Input Queues with 64-byte commands.
00586 
00587     By default, all the Input Queues are configured to use the 32-byte PCI
00588     command format. To use the 64-byte format, edit the configuration data
00589     in components/driver/host/include/oct_config_data.h to change the
00590     instr_type field in the input queue configuration from 32 to 64.
00591 
00592     Refer to \ref Octdevconf "Section: OCTEON device configuration" to learn
00593     more about editing OCTEON configuration.
00594 
00595     When using a input queue with 64-byte command, the first 32 bytes in the
00596     command generated by the driver are identical to the 32-byte command
00597     described in \ref rr-cmd32 "PCI command format". The remaining 32 bytes 
00598     are read from the 4 64-bit exhdr fields in the OCTEON_soft_request_t
00599     structure.
00600 
00601     The setting of the Input queue is transparent to the host application and
00602     the data bytes from the exhdr and from the input data buffer appear in the
00603     same way in the WQE received by the application running on the OCTEON cores
00604     irrespective of the command type set for the Input queues.
00605 
00606 
00607 
00608 
00609 <br>
00610    \subsection  user_samp  user-space application example sources
00611 
00612     The user-space application example (oct_req) under components/driver/host/test demonstrates request processing using the OCTEON PCI driver. It requires the <b>cvmcs</b> core application which can be found at applications/pci-core-app/base.
00613 
00614 */
